item.title: Covid vaccine: All over-50s and high risk groups offered first dose
item.description: Ministers meet a target of inviting the top nine priority groups to receive the vaccine by 15 April.

item.title: Covid-19: England gets third jab as Moderna rollout begins
item.description: It offers an alternative to the AstraZeneca jab for under-30s, after very rare blood clot concerns.

item.title: Covid lockdown eases: England 'buzzing' after first night out in 97 days
item.description: As outdoor hospitality reopens, revellers find the atmosphere "celebratory" despite a nip in the air.

item.title: Daunte Wright shooting by police in Minnesota 'accidental'
item.description: The officer who shot Daunte Wright mistook her gun for a Taser, police say, as crowds defy a curfew.

item.title: Cressida Cowell: Children's Laureate leads call for £100m primary school library fund
item.description: Cressida Cowell and other writers want yearly funding to aid primary school libraries post-pandemic.

item.title: George Floyd's younger sibling tells court: 'I miss my brother'
item.description: George Floyd's younger brother gave evidence as the prosecution ended its case against Derek Chauvin.

item.title: World's wealthiest 'at heart of climate problem'
item.description: The so-called “polluter elite” must change their lifestyles to tackle climate change, a report says.

item.title: Fukushima: Japan approves releasing wastewater into ocean
item.description: Most experts say it's a normal and safe practice but environmentalists and locals are not happy.

item.title: Covid: Surge testing in Wandsworth and Lambeth after South African variant cluster found
item.description: NHS Test and Trace says 44 cases confirmed in Wandsworth and 30 probable is 'significant' number.

item.title: Taiwan: 'Record number' of China jets enter airspace
item.description: Beijing sends 25 military aircraft into Taiwan as the US warns against an 'increasingly aggressive' China.

item.title: Gruppe S: German far-right group on trial for 'terror plot'
item.description: The 12 men are accused of planning attacks on migrants, Muslims and politicians in Germany.

item.title: Uefa Euro 2020: Trafalgar Square earmarked for 12,500-capacity fan park
item.description: Up to nine matches could be shown on giant TV screens in central London if licensing is approved.

item.title: Newspaper headlines: Brothers' tributes and Cameron 'welcomes' inquiry
item.description: The papers cover the princes' gratitude to their grandfather and a probe into the ex-PM's lobbying.

item.title: Lockdown lifting in Liverpool: 'Light at the end of the tunnel'
item.description: Excitement, relief and cocktails flowed as bars and non-essential shops reopened in Liverpool.

item.title: Covid: 'The world through my eyes is different'
item.description: Usha Mistry has very limited sight and is worried about having to move around London as lockdown eases.

item.title: Saving the kelp forest that stars in My Octopus Teacher
item.description: The makers of the Bafta-winning documentary want to preserve the underwater ecosystem it features.

item.title: Covid: 'I'm very happy to have my hairdresser back'
item.description: Hairdressers reopen in England for the first time in months, along with pubs, shops and gyms.

item.title: Primark: Norwich shoppers undeterred by long queue
item.description: A bustling Norwich city centre marks a welcome return to High Street shopping as lockdown eases.

item.title: Where has the spring weather gone?
item.description: BBC Weather presenter, Owain Wyn Evans, explains the chilly temperatures and teaches us a new word.

item.title: Yuri Gagarin: Sixty years since the first man went into space
item.description: The BBC speaks to the woman who, as a child, witnessed Yuri Gagarin's return to Earth 60 years ago.

item.title: Love Island: Could Tinder find the show's first gay couple?
item.description: The ITV show has hooked up with the dating app to find this summer's hopeful singletons.

item.title: In pictures: Shoppers and gym-goers enjoy lockdown easing
item.description: Hairdressers and zoos also reopened in England, with pubs and restaurants welcoming customers outside.

item.title: Bafta Film Awards 2021: Nomadland and Promising Young Woman win big
item.description: The drama wins four prizes including best film, while Promising Young Woman wins best British film.

item.title: Pubs reopen in England: Gong marks the occasion
item.description: The Greyhound Inn in Buxton is one of many pubs in England open for outside seating from today.

item.title: Bafta Film Awards 2021: Red carpet in pictures
item.description: The biggest night in the British film calendar, the Bafta Awards, is taking place in London.

item.title: The anti-vax movement targeting German children
item.description: An anti-lockdown, anti-vaccine movement with ties to the far right has recruited hundreds of children.

item.title: Quick guide to Russia-Ukraine military tensions
item.description: What you need to know about Russia's troop build-up around eastern Ukraine.

item.title: 'I put those goggles on and just fell in love'
item.description: Drones capable of 90mph are being raced in a league which supporters say is close to the big time.

item.title: What is Ramadan and when is it?
item.description: Ramadan is one of the most important events in the Islamic calendar, but it's been affected by lockdown.

item.title: The exchange project uniting young Americans during the pandemic
item.description: Teenagers from across the US are coming together to discuss their vastly differing backgrounds.

item.title: Covid accelerates India's millionaire exodus
item.description: As Covid cases surge, India's wealthy lead global enquiries for citizenship and residency abroad.

item.title: Will the suspension of campaigning affect the Holyrood election?
item.description: Holyrood election campaigning is to resume but will the suspension have any impact on the election?

item.title: Prince Philip: The Vanuatu tribes mourning the death of their 'god'
item.description: As Britain grieves his death, so do some Pacific tribespeople who revere him as a spiritual figure.

item.title: Greensill: The questions still facing David Cameron
item.description: The ex-prime minister's post-Downing Street business career is coming under increased scrutiny.

item.title: Shirley Williams: Pioneer who tried to reshape politics
item.description: An obituary of the former Labour cabinet minister, one of the SDP "Gang of Four" who became a Lib Dem peer.

item.title: Iran nuclear attack: Mystery surrounds nuclear sabotage at Natanz
item.description: Iran blames Israel, but was this a cyber attack or physical act of sabotage?

item.title: The Friends reunion has been filmed in Los Angeles. Here's what we know
item.description: The Friends cast reunited after almost 17 years last week. Here's all we know about the one-off show.

item.title: The 'Iron Man' body armour many of us may soon be wearing
item.description: The market for exoskeletons - high-tech external body support systems - is tipped to grow strongly.

item.title: Covid and twins: 'Huge' impact of lockdown separation
item.description: Three sets of twins reflect on the past year, with research suggesting only 5.5% live together.

item.title: Oxford Street: Wooing shoppers back to Europe's busiest high street
item.description: Empty stores and American sweets - what consumers on Oxford Street can expect to see as shops reopen.

item.title: Bafta Film Awards 2021: Snobbery, pianos and other takeaways
item.description: Even with social distancing there was plenty of humour, glamour and surprises at the virtual event.

item.title: 'Back-to-back wins give West Brom hope and belief' - Allardyce
item.description: Sam Allardyce says "people's ears are starting to prick up" after West Brom make it back-to-back Premier League wins for the first time this season with victory over Southampton.

item.title: Brighton edge towards safety with draw against Everton
item.description: Brighton edge a point closer to Premier League safety with a goalless draw against Everton at Amex Stadium.

item.title: Who should stop dancing to be taken seriously? - Garth Crooks' team of the week
item.description: Who is playing at the top of their game and who should leave out the dance moves? It's all in Garth Crooks' team of the week.

item.title: Sports move fixtures to avoid clash with Prince Philip funeral
item.description: The Premier League, EFL, Premiership Rugby and British Horseracing change schedules on Saturday to avoid clashing with Prince Philip's funeral.

item.title: Camera position means VAR unable to reverse offside decision on West Brom 'goal'
item.description: The video assistant referee is unable to reverse an offside decision that ruled out a West Brom goal because of the positioning of the camera.

item.title: Vote: Who's the greatest player in WSL history?
item.description: As the WSL reaches its 10-year anniversary, BBC Sport asks who is the greatest player in the history of the competition?

item.title: Women's Super League: Gilly Flaherty scores the first WSL goal
item.description: To mark 10 years of the Women's Super League, watch the first goal as Gilly Flaherty scores for Arsenal in a 1-0 win over Chelsea on 13 April 2011.

item.title: Coronavirus: What's happening with pools, haircuts and gyms?
item.description: Lockdown has been eased further - but what does it mean for hairdressers, pubs and gyms?

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: What are the rules for weddings and when can I hold a reception?
item.description: Wedding ceremonies are still restricted across the UK, but the rules are easing.

item.title: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: Pub gardens and non-essential shops can now open in England - as part of the next stage of easing lockdown rules.

item.title: What is the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine?
item.description: People under 30 are being offered an alternative to the AstraZeneca vaccine after a review into rare blood clots.

item.title: Covid: Restaurants and pubs have reopened, but what are the rules?
item.description: Pubs, cafes and restaurants in England can now open for customers seated outdoors.

item.title: Lockdown easing: What to watch for when you’re out and about
item.description: The BBC’s David Shukman on how to navigate lockdown easing while keeping yourself and others safe.

item.title: AstraZeneca vaccine: How do you weigh up the risks and benefits?
item.description: A guide to the risks and benefits of receiving the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid: When can I go on holiday abroad or in the UK?
item.description: Anyone in England who travels abroad without good reason will soon face a £5000 fine.

item.title: How many people can I have a drink with? And other questions
item.description: We answer some of your questions about England's roadmap out of lockdown, and other Covid-related issues.

item.title: England lockdown: Countdown to freedom
item.description: As coronavirus restrictions are lifted - when can you return to your favourite activities?

item.title: What are the UK plans for Covid passports?
item.description: The government is considering how people could prove they are unlikely to transmit Covid.

item.title: Rare blood clots - what you need to know
item.description: We take a look at why these unusual clots happen and when they occur.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: Under-30s will be not be offered the AstraZeneca vaccine, after concerns over rare blood clots.

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 32 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: Covid: How are European countries tackling the pandemic?
item.description: Are European countries relaxing restrictions put in place to control a new wave of infections?

item.title: Covid: How to get a test for coronavirus
item.description: What are the tests for coronavirus, who are they for, and how do they work?

item.title: Covid: What is the rule of six and what are the social distancing rules?
item.description: Lockdown rules are being eased further in England and Wales so more people can meet up outside.

item.title: Covid: Can my boss force me to go to work?
item.description: As lockdown restrictions ease ease gradually across the UK, what are the rules about going to work?

item.title: Covid vaccines: How fast is progress around the world?
item.description: Charts and maps tracking the progress of Covid vaccination programmes.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules for places of worship?
item.description: Places of worship are open across much of the UK, despite lockdown.

item.title: Coronavirus: Your tributes to those who have died
item.description: A collection of your tributes to some of the thousands of people in the UK who have died with coronavirus.

item.title: Why is the EU unhappy with AstraZeneca?
item.description: The EU has called on AstraZeneca to "catch up" on its deliveries to the EU.

item.title: Covid: What’s the problem with the EU vaccine rollout?
item.description: The coronavirus vaccine is being rolled out across the EU but there have been delays.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules for face masks or face coverings?
item.description: As the UK cautiously unlocks, experts will review the evidence on when and where masks are needed.

item.title: Unemployment rate: How many people are out of work?
item.description: The unemployment rate is rising as Covid hits different parts of the economy.

item.title: Covid: What's happened to crime during the pandemic?
item.description: From dog theft to drug crime, lockdown has led to some big changes in policing.

item.title: Covid: The inside story of the government's battle against the virus
item.description: Twenty of Downing Street's most senior politicians, officials and former officials take you "into the room" where essential Covid decisions were being made.

item.title: Covid: The countries that nailed it, and what we can learn from them
item.description: A year into the pandemic, we look at countries that have had some success in tackling the virus.

item.title: Prince Philip: How can Prince Harry attend the funeral?
item.description: The Duke of Sussex has returned to the UK for the first time since "stepping back" from royal duties.

item.title: Prince Philip: A simple, family farewell
item.description: A no-nonsense moderniser, the duke's last service to the monarchy may be in the way he departs it, reports the BBC's Jonny Dymond.

item.title: Gyles Brandreth: 'Prince Philip would have been touched by public reaction'
item.description: Writer and broadcaster Gyles Brandreth, royal biographer and a friend of Prince Philip, reflects on the public response to his death.

item.title: Prince Charles on Prince Philip: 'My family and I miss my father enormously'
item.description: Prince Charles said his father "would have been amazed by... the touching things that have been said".

item.title: Prince Philip: A turbulent childhood stalked by exile, mental illness and death
item.description: In marrying, Philip was able to regain the "simple pleasures" of family life he had lost aged eight.

item.title: Prince Philip on royal duty: In his own words
item.description: For some, the Duke of Edinburgh will be remembered most vividly for his public comments.

item.title: Prince Philip tributes: 'I wanted my grandchildren to remember this day'
item.description: People from all generations have come to Windsor to pay tribute to Prince Philip after his death.

item.title: When the Queen was snapped 'giggling' at Prince Philip
item.description: A royal occasion descended into bewilderment and chuckles after a swarm of bees descended.

item.title: Prince Philip: How the Royal Navy shaped the Duke of Edinburgh
item.description: From his rescue as a toddler to thwarting wartime sea raids, the duke - and his outlook on life - was shaped by the navy.

item.title: The Queen and Prince Philip: An enduring royal romance
item.description: During their 73-year marriage, he was the Queen's public support and the person who knew her best.

item.title: Prince Philip: Matt Smith and Tobias Menzies on playing the duke in The Crown
item.description: What was it like to take on the part of the Duke of Edinburgh in the award-winning Netflix series?

item.title: Philip tributes: 'A rock, a hero and one of a kind'
item.description: Members of the public gather at Buckingham Palace to lay flowers and show support for the Queen.

item.title: Prince Philip: Duke's support for Aberfan families remembered
item.description: The duke visited the devastated village within hours of the tragedy that claimed 144 lives.

item.title: Prince Philip: Death of the Duke of Edinburgh announced
item.description: Crowds gathered outside Buckingham Palace and Windsor Castle and people laid floral tributes.

item.title: Prince Philip: The Duke of Edinburgh's Award 'saved me from jail'
item.description: For pals James and Nathan, the awards are about more than hauling badly-packed rucksacks up hills.

item.title: Obituary: HRH The Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh
item.description: Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, won widespread respect for his steadfast and constant support of the Queen.

item.title: Prince Philip: 99 years, 143 countries and one very famous wife
item.description: He was the man beside Queen Elizabeth II - and arguably the world's most famous husband.

item.title: The announcement of the death of Prince Philip
item.description: The BBC's announcement as Buckingham Palace confirms the death of Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh.

item.title: Race report: Was controversy part of the plan?
item.description: How the government handled the release of a contentious report on racial disparity in the UK.

item.title: 'We found a baby on the subway - now he's our son'
item.description: Danny Stewart saw something on the floor of an NY subway station - soon he would treasure it more than anything.

item.title: Letterbox contact: ‘Don’t my birth children have a right to know I’m dying?'
item.description: Diagnosed with a terminal illness, Hanna wanted to tell the twins taken from her at 16 - but had no way of reaching them.
